posts.title: Welcome to My Retro Blog
posts.excerpt: Check out my new blog section with a classic retro vibe. A space where I'll share my thoughts on tech, development, and everything in between.
posts.content:
Welcome to my retro-styled blog! I've built this space to share my journey in software development, machine learning, and the ever-evolving world of technology.

This blog features a classic CRT monitor aesthetic with that nostalgic purple-pink glow we all love. It's built with vanilla JavaScript, keeping things simple and fast - no frameworks needed.

I'll be writing about my experiences with microservices architecture, ML pipelines, and the interesting challenges I encounter while building scalable systems. Stay tuned for more posts!
posts.author: Elvis Moraa

posts.title: Building with Vanilla JS in 2025
posts.excerpt: Why I still love vanilla JavaScript and how it keeps my projects fast and maintainable. Sometimes simpler is better.
posts.content:
In an era dominated by React, Vue, and Angular, there's something refreshing about building with pure vanilla JavaScript. Don't get me wrong - I use frameworks professionally and they're great for complex applications.

But for projects like this portfolio, vanilla JS offers several advantages:

  • Zero dependencies - No node_modules folder weighing down your project
  • Lightning fast - No framework overhead means instant loading
  • Complete control - You understand every line of code
  • No build process - Just write, save, and refresh

This blog system fetches data from a simple JSON file, renders cards dynamically, and handles navigation - all with vanilla JavaScript. It's a great reminder that you don't always need a framework to build something functional and beautiful.

posts.title: The Art of Retro Web Design
posts.excerpt: Exploring the nostalgic aesthetics of early computing and how to bring that retro feeling to modern web projects.
posts.content:
There's a growing trend of retro-inspired web design, and for good reason. The aesthetics of early computing - CRT monitors, pixelated fonts, neon glows - evoke a sense of nostalgia while standing out in today's clean, minimalist web.

Key Elements of Retro Design

Pixelated Fonts: Fonts like Silkscreen bring that classic 8-bit feel. They remind us of early video games and DOS terminals.

CRT Effects: Box shadows and subtle glows simulate the phosphor glow of old monitors. It's all about that soft, hazy edge.

Limited Color Palettes: Purple and pink (#522252) create that classic cyberpunk vibe. High contrast works great for readability too.

Scanlines & Noise: Subtle effects that mimic screen artifacts add authenticity without being distracting.

The trick is balancing nostalgia with usability. You want the aesthetic without sacrificing accessibility or performance. This portfolio strikes that balance - retro styling with modern web standards underneath.
